properties.name: Animeshlochana Chaitya
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Animeshlochana Chaitya 7th Century (or later) C.E. This white structure commemorates the Second Week after Gautama’s enlightenment where he sat in meditation with motionless eyes fixated on the Bodhi Tree. It is 55 feet tall and is a miniature representation of the Mahabodhi temple itself.

properties.name: Ashokan Pillar
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Ashokan Pillar 3rd Century B.C.E. The lower portion of this is still found in-situ and inscribed on it is Ashoka’s famous “schism” edict, a threatening message warning of the expulsion for dissentient monks (according to Debela Mitra). The lion capital is detached and housed at the nearby Sarnath museum, which is now famous because portions have been adopted as the State crest of modern India.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Location: Bihar, India Age: c. 1600-2100 years Buddhist Significance: Bodh-Gaya is the historical location of Buddha Gautama’s enlightenment. According to tradition, Siddhartha Gautama sat underneath a papal (or fig) tree and attained enlightenment. Considered the most holy of all Buddhist pilgrimage sites, the Mahabodhi temple complex commemorates this event with a living ancestor of the original Bodhi tree, a magnificent temple, dozens of votive stupas, and other landmarks designating important locations where Gautama practiced.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Bodh-Gaya, IndiaPlease see The Buddhist Map of Bodh-Gaya for extensive detail on this archaeological site.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Chankama
properties.description: Posted by Mdm111st Century B.C.E. A raised platform honors the location where Gautama performed walking meditation during the Third Week after enlightenment. The sacred spot has many representations of blossoming lotuses which sprung up underneath his footsteps. An interesting aspect of this elongated feature is that it is aligned cockeyed, showing that it was once properly aligned with an older Mahabodhi temple.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Mahabodhi Temple
properties.description: Posted by Mdm114-5th Centuries C.E. The foundations of the present brick Mahabodhi Temple date to the Gupta period. An earlier, possibly Ashokan structure was either modified into the present chaitya or was destroyed entirely. Inside the chaitya today is a large two metre tall image of Gautama in Bhumisparsha mudra, the form he took to attain enlightenment. The Mahabodhi chaitya has been subjected to numerous damages and renovations over the years but is still a glorious site to behold.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Mahabodhi Tree
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Bodh (Pipal or Fig) Tree An ancestor of the original tree in which Gautama reached enlightenment under, the current tree is located behind the Mahabodhi shrine and over the jeweled Vajrasana. This tree is arguably the most important spot in all of Buddhism. The tree itself is a venerable object and symbolizes Gautama himself in much imagery. The bodhi tree is often represented in early Buddhist art as found on reliefs from many Buddhist sites throughout South Asia.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Muchilinda Lake (or Lotus Lake)
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Muchilinda Lake (or Lotus Lake) In the Sixth Week after enlightenment, Gautama was sheltered from a thunderstorm by the Naga King Muchilinda who used his hoods as umbrellas. Today the event is commemorated in the Mahabodhi complex by an exquisite sculpture and pond to the south of the Mahabodhi temple. Pilgrims come to feed the catfish that inhabit the pond.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Rajayatana Tree
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Rajayatana Tree Gautama spent the Seventh Week after enlightenment meditating underneath the Rajayatana Tree. This place is especially sacred to Burmese Buddhists because two Burmese merchants became the first lay devotees of the Buddha by taking refuge in the Buddha and the Dharma (not the Sangha, because, according to tradition, the Sangha did not yet exist). Hairs were taken from Gautama to Burma to be venerated.

properties.name: Bodh-Gaya: Ratanaghara
properties.description: Posted by Mdm117th Century (or later) C.E . The Ratanaghara chaitya commemorates the location where Gautama spent the Fourth Week in meditation. This roofless “Jewel House” is where Gautama reflected on Patthana and the Abhidhamma, the Third Basket. Tradition has it that five colors emanated from Gautama’s body to form a fantastic sixth color. Today the chaitya is still roofless and is venerated by pilgrims.

properties.name: Dhamekh Stupa
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Dhamekh Stupa Interior date: Unknown Exterior Date: 300-600 C.E. This stupa has been called the most imposing monument at Sarnath. It is 93 feet in diameter and 143 feet tall and is a solid structure. A variety of beautiful and interesting reliefs line the exterior as pilgrims circumambulate still today. It is unknown what the stupa honors, however a stone slab found in the center is inscribed with the Buddhist creed.

properties.name: Dharmarajika Stupa
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Dharmarajika Stupa 2nd or 3rd Century B.C.E. This stupa could possibly date to the Mauryan period, but because of six enlargements and its ultimate destruction in the 18th century C.E., it is difficult to date. A sandstone box containing a green marble relic-casket was found at its core and held human bone, decayed pearls, gold leaves and other jewels. Today the remains of the stupa are used for rituals conducted by pilgrims.

properties.name: Monastery 51
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Monastery 51 6-7th Century C.E. Raised over an earlier monastery, this monastery, or vihara, contains 22 cells and a large courtyard. It is one of the most aesthetically perfect extant viharas on the site.

properties.name: Mulagandhakuti (Chief Shrine)
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Mulagandhakuti (Chief Shrine) 300 – 600 C.E. (Gupta period) Nearly 60 square feet, this structure is surrounded by many clusters of small votive stupas. Though most likely not the original location of the Mulagandhakuti, the extant location is an elaborate temple meant to house holy images of Buddha Gautama. Several chapels extend from three sides that show the auspicious nature of this feature. The primary object of worship has never been found.

properties.name: Sanchi
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Location: Madya Pradesh, India Age: c. 2200 years old Buddhist Significance: The Mahastupa in the center of the complex that honors Buddha Gautama has been a major pilgrimage spot for centuries. Ashoka built this monastic complex on the outskirts of ancient Vedisha probably for a number of reasons: 1.) Vedisha and Ujjain were large local commerce centers and the Sanchi hilltop is a visible location for traveling Buddhist merchants; 2.) Tradition has it that Ashoka built the Sanchi monastic complex to honor his wife’s birth location. In sum, the Sanchi monastic complex is elaborate and, next to the various mounds in and around Taxila in Pakistan, is one of the most thoroughly excavated and best preserved Buddhist sites in South Asia.

properties.name: Sanchi: Chaitya 18
properties.description: Posted by Mdm117th Century C.E. This is an extant apsidal hall constructed on top of a Shungan apsidal hall.

properties.name: Sanchi: Stupa 1
properties.description: Posted by Mdm112nd Century B.C.E. This “Great Stupa” is famous for the Buddhist art seen on its reliefs. It is the prototypical Buddhist stupa and has become the “face” of Buddhist archaeology. Relics and/or ashes of Gautama himself have been traditionally viewed as housed inside this large structure. However, no such relics and/or ashes have been discovered. Modern day pilgrims often circumambulate this Mahastupa, perhaps just as ancient Buddhists did.

properties.name: Sanchi: Stupa 2
properties.description: Posted by Mdm113rd Century B.C.E. Built before stupa 1’s present form, stupa 2 is famous and interesting because it houses the remains of several ancient Buddhist “saints.” Another key feature of this stupa is that it is built on the side of the Sanchi hill, as opposed to stupa 1 which is the centerpiece of the monastic complex. Vinaya code states that stupas honoring deceased monastics are to be built lower than ones honoring Gautama.

properties.name: Sanchi: Stupa 3
properties.description: Posted by Mdm111st Century C.E. This stupa honors Gautama’s disciples Sariputra and Mahamoggalana. In the middle of the 19th century, British archaeologists Alexander Cunningham and F.C. Maisey excavated the stupa and found relic caskets, one having the initials “Sa” and the other “Ma,” thus verifying that this stupa honors Sariputra and Mahamoggalana.

properties.name: Sanchi: Temple 40
properties.description: Posted by Mdm113rd and 2nd Centuries B.C.E. The earliest temple on the site was originally built as an apsidal hall during Ashoka’s time. It was later enlarged in the 2nd century B.C.E. In its last addition, the hall came into its present form in the 7th or 8th century C.E.

properties.name: Sarnath
properties.description: Posted by Mdm11Location: Uttar Pradesh, India Age: c. 1800-2300 years Buddhist Significance: Located only four miles north of Varanasi, Sarnath is the site where Buddha Gautama gave his first sermon. Known as Mrigadaya, or Deer Park, Sarnath has four prominent features: 1.) the Dhamekh stupa; 2.) the Dharmarajika stupa; 3.) Mulagandhakuti (main shrine); and 4.) the Ashokan pillar. All around the site at various locations are many small votive stupas that literally dot the landscape from above. Sarnath is one of the four holiest Buddhist pilgrimage sites.
